docs.lead_paragraph: A bill moving through the California Legislature could make it possible for children to have three or four legal parents, not just two. There are some objections.

headline.seo: A California Bill Would Legalize Third- and Fourth-Parent Adoptions
headline.main: Measure Opens Door to Three Parents, or Four
headline.print_headline: Measure Opens Door To 3 Parents, or More

docs.abstract: Bill moving through the California Legislature could make it possible for children to have three or four legal parents, opening the door for alternative families to seek legal recognition of their relationships; the bill is opposed by some conservative groups, who say it is an attempt to radically redefine the family.
docs.snippet: A bill moving through the California Legislature could make it possible for children to have three or four legal parents, not just two. There are some objections.

docs.lead_paragraph: A vice chairman of Democratic Socialists of America responds to an Op-Ed article by the Czech-born film director Milos Forman.
docs.snippet: A vice chairman of Democratic Socialists of America responds to an Op-Ed article by the Czech-born film director Milos Forman.

docs.lead_paragraph: Captive insurance companies can save money on premiums, reduce income taxes and transfer money to heirs free of estate taxes, but they also carry the potential for abuse.

headline.seo: A Captive Insurance Company Offers Financial Benefits, if Not Abused - Wealth Matters
headline.main: An Insurer of One’s Own? It’s Possible, With Caveats
headline.print_headline: An Insurer of One’s Own? It’s Possible, With Caveats

docs.abstract: Paul Sullivan Wealth Matters column investigates the merits of captive insurance companies, private insurers that are wholly owned subsidiaries of another company; contends that captives can save money on premiums, reduce income taxes and transfer money to heirs free of estate taxes, but they also carry the potential for abuse.
docs.snippet: Captive insurance companies can save money on premiums, reduce income taxes and transfer money to heirs free of estate taxes, but they also carry the potential for abuse.

docs.abstract: I spent three days picking a Medicare drug plan. I'm praying I got the right one.
docs.snippet: I spent three days picking a Medicare drug plan. I'm praying I got the right one.

headline.main: New Service Shares Your Medical Information

docs.abstract: Emergencylink.com allows travelers to upload their medical records and designate emergency contacts.
docs.snippet: Emergencylink.com allows travelers to upload their medical records and designate emergency contacts.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Steve Beshear, a Democrat, has alerted the federal government of his intention to create a statewide health insurance exchange to help Kentuckians find affordable coverage.

headline.main: Kentucky: State Commits to Insurance Exchange
headline.print_headline: Kentucky: State Commits To Insurance Exchange

docs.snippet: Gov. Steve Beshear, a Democrat, has alerted the federal government of his intention to create a statewide health insurance exchange to help Kentuckians find affordable coverage.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Scott has vowed to reject the expansion of Medicaid, a major plank of the health care law, but advocates for the poor and some players in the health care industry — especially hospitals — intend to push back.

headline.seo: In Florida, a Fight Brews Over Governor’s Vow to Opt Out of Medicaid Expansion
headline.main: Lines Are Drawn Over Opting Out of Medicaid Plan
headline.print_headline: Lines Are Drawn Over Opting Out Of Medicaid Plan

docs.abstract: Gov Rick Scott of Florida and other Republican governors have vowed that they will reject the expansion of Medicaid under Pres Obama's health care law, but may find it a difficult task to accomplish; advocates for the poor and some valuable political players in the health care industry intend to push back; Florida, the fourth most populous state, has more than 20 percent of its residents lacking health insurance, so Scott's agenda would have significant impact on the overall plan to insure all Americans.
docs.snippet: Gov. Rick Scott has vowed to reject the expansion of Medicaid, a major plank of the health care law, but advocates for the poor and some players in the health care industry — especially hospitals — intend to push back.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

headline.main: Study Links Risky Driving Behaviors to Heightened Mortality, On and Off the Road

docs.abstract: Researchers concluded that motorists with serious violations on their records were significantly more likely to have a higher mortality than those with clean records.
docs.snippet: Researchers concluded that motorists with serious violations on their records were significantly more likely to have a higher mortality than those with clean records.

headline.main: Two Medical Students Navigate the Health Care Maze

docs.abstract: What do all of the changes in health care mean for a new generation of doctors? "The Health Care Handbook," written by two medical students at Washington University, is an astonishingly clear "user's manual" that explains our health care system and the policies that will shape it in the years to come.

docs.lead_paragraph: Debate in the House suggested the fight over how to remake the health care system would continue next year regardless of who wins the elections for Congress and president.

headline.seo: House Votes, Again, to Repeal Obama Health Care Law
headline.main: Repeal of Health Care Law Approved, Again, by House
headline.print_headline: Repeal of Health Care Law Approved, Again, by House

docs.abstract: House of Representatives votes 244 to 185 to repeal the health care overhaul less than two weeks after the Supreme Court upheld it as constitutional; vote, which has no chance of approval in the Senate, exposes the depth of passion over efforts to remake the health care system, and suggests that the fight will continue into 2013, regardless of who wins the presidency.
docs.snippet: Debate in the House suggested the fight over how to remake the health care system would continue next year regardless of who wins the elections for Congress and president.
